title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS – On a night where offense was a precious commodity, one man refused to be denied. Luka Doncic authored a performance for the ages, single-handedly overpowering the Cleveland Cavaliers to will the Dallas Mavericks to an 84-77 victory in a 1998 defensive slugfest.

While both teams struggled to find an offensive rhythm, Doncic operated on a different plane entirely. The Cavaliers, led by Donovan Mitchell’s valiant 31-point effort, simply had no answer. Every contested jumper, every drive through a thicket of defenders, and every step-back three from Doncic felt like a monumental event, chipping away at Cleveland’s resolve.

The game was a grind, a war of attrition reflected in the final score. Yet, Doncic’s historic 47 points were a stunning anomaly, a supernova in an otherwise dark offensive sky. He didn't just score; he *was* the offense, accounting for well over half of his team's total output and dragging the Mavericks across the finish line.

Mitchell’s 31 points, a stellar night in any other context, were rendered a footnote by Doncic’s utter dominance. The Cavaliers' defense, which held the rest of the Mavericks in check, was left broken and searching for answers that did not exist.

In the record books, this will go down as a defensive team win for Dallas. But in the annals of history, it will forever be remembered as the night Luka Doncic scored 47 points and beat the Cleveland Cavaliers almost by himself. It was not just a win; it was an indelible statement from a force of nature.
